sect1.title: Creating a New Package
sect1.para: This section covers how to create packages for an arbitrary software project, which we will refer to here as the upstream project. We assume that this project contains source code which you want to package for one or more &suse; (openSUSE) distributions. We assume the setup of your home project in your &obsa; instance is already done. If not, refer to .
To create a package from the upstream project, do the following:

sect1.title: Investigating the Local Build Process
sect1.para: It is hard to describe a general procedure when you encounter a build error. Most build errors are very specific to the package being built. However, there are generic tools that often help:

sect2.title: Build Log
sect2.para: Each build produces a log file on &obsa;. This log file can be viewed by the buildlog (or bl) subcommand. It needs a build target which is the distribution and the architecture.
However, this command will print the complete build log which could be difficult to spot the errors. Use the buildlogtail subcommand to show only the end of the log file:
Additionally, the &osccmd; creates some build log files in the build directory /var/tmp/build-root/:

listitem.para: Contains the command which is used to build the package. For RPM-like systems it is rpmbuild -ba PACKAGE.spec.
Contains the path to all object files.

sect2.title: Local Build Root Directory
sect2.para: If you build a package locally and you get a build error, investigate the problems in the build root directory directly. This is sometimes easier and more effective than only looking at the build log.
By default, the directory /var/tmp/build-root/ is used as the build root. This is defined in the configuration file ~/.oscrc using the key build-root.
Each combination of distribution and architecture has its own build root. To change into the build root for &tw; on the x86-64 architecture, use the following command:
Your shell will then change to the directory /home/abuild belonging to the user abuild in group abuild.

sect2.para: The build root contains the following structure:

example.title: Directory Structure of a Build Root (/var/tmp/build-root/)
example.screen: /home/abuild/ └── rpmbuild ├── BUILD ├── BUILDROOT ├── OTHER ├── RPMS │ ├── i386 │ ├── noarch │ └── x86_64 ├── SOURCES ├── SPECS └── SRPMS

callout.para: Contains directory named after the package name. In spec files, the name of the package directory is referenced using the %buildroot macro.
If the build process was unable to create a package, this directory contains all files and directories which are installed in the target system through the %install section of the spec file.
If the package has been successfully built, this directory will be emptied.
If the build was successful, stores binary RPMs into subdirectories of architecture (for example, noarch or x86_64).
All source files from the working copy will be copied here.
Stores source RPMs into this directory.

sect1.title: Adding Dependencies to Your Project
sect1.para: Software usually depends on other software: To run an application, you may, for example, need additional libraries. Such dependencies are called installation requirements.

sect1.para: Additionally, there are also dependencies that are only necessary for building a package but not when the software it contains is run. Such dependencies are called build requirements.
The &obs; provides the following methods to handle both dependencies in your projects:

sect2.para: In a spec file, dependencies are expressed with the keywords Requires (installation requirements) and BuildRequires (installation requirements). Both belong to the header of the spec file.

sect2.title: Associating Other Repositories with Your Repository
sect2.para: There is no need to duplicate the work of others. If you need a specific package which is available in another repository, you can reference this repository in your project metadata. This is called layering.
When a package is needed, it can be installed from another other repository (see the note below).
To add another repository that can be used as build or installation requirements, do the following:

step.para: Open a terminal.
Edit the project metadata:
Search for repository elements. For example, to allow usage packages from devel:languages:python in a &tw; project, extend the repository element with:

note.title: Order Is Important
note.para: The order of the path elements is important: path elements are searched from top to bottom.
If a package cannot be found in the first repository, the second repository is considered. When the first suitable package is found, it is installed and the build preparation can continue.
For practical reasons, additional repositories should be added before the standard repositories of the specified distribution.

step.para: Add more path elements under the same repository element.
If necessary, repeat and to add path elements to repository elements of other distributions or releases.

sect2.title: Reusing Packages in Your Project

sect2.para: To reuse existing packages in your package repository, &obsa; offers two methods: aggregating and linking.
sect2.remark: toms 2017-08-30: add a notes when NOT to use the two methods.

sect3.title: Aggregating a Package
sect3.para: An aggregate package is a pointer to an &obsa; package. Such package and the result of it are referenced int another project. Aggregating is used in the following situations:

listitem.para: No changes in the source code are needed.
Packages that are needed for building are only available in a different project.
Build results (binaries) of the aggregated package are copied into the target's package repository.

sect3.title: Linking a Package
sect3.para: A linked package is a clone of another package with additional modifications. Linking is used in the following situations:

listitem.para: The source code needs changes, but the source either cannot be changed in the original package or doing so is impractical or inconvenient to change the source.
To separate the original source from own patches.

sect3.screen: &prompt.user;&osccmd; up --unexpand-link Unexpanding to rev 1 A _link D pytest-3.2.1.tar.gz D python-pytest-doc.changes D python-pytest-doc.spec D python-pytest.changes D python-pytest.spec At revision 1.

sect1.title: Manage Group
sect1.para: Users with Maintainer rights can add users to their group and remove users from it. They can also give other users Maintainer rights.
